org.tmotte.tmplz.parse.tokenize

Class DocumentTokenizer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.tmotte.tmplz.parse.tokenize.DocumentTokenizer

  • public class DocumentTokenizer
extends java.lang.Object
    DocumentTokenizer is responsible for parsing a template into Token objects. It can be overridden to provide custom parsing behaviors. The default tag delimiters can be changed via DocumentTokenizer's constructors. The tag names themselves (nameSlot, nameSection, etc.) can only be changed by overriding the class and setting them in a constructor (customizing tag names doesn't seem like a very useful thing to do, however). DocumentTokenizer is thread-safe.
    See Also:
    TemplateManager.setTagDelimiters(String,String), TemplateManager.setTokenizer(DocumentTokenizer)

    • Constructor Detail

      • DocumentTokenizer

        public DocumentTokenizer()

      • DocumentTokenizer

        public DocumentTokenizer(java.lang.String startOfTag,
                 java.lang.String endOfTag)
        This allows you to create a custom Tokenizer that uses different demarcation tags. Usually set via TemplateManager.setTagDelimiters().
        Parameters:
        startOfTag - The characters that mark the start of a tag.
        endOfTag - The characters that mark the end of a tag.
        See Also:
        TemplateManager.setTokenizer(DocumentTokenizer), TemplateManager.setTagDelimiters(String,String)

    • Method Detail

      • setAutoTrim

        public void setAutoTrim(boolean autoTrim)
        Turns on/off auto trim of tags on lines by themselves. Usually set via TemplateManager.
        See Also:
        TemplateManager.setAutoTrim(boolean)

      • getTokenName

        public final java.lang.String getTokenName(Token t)

      • parse

        public TokenList parse(java.lang.String source)
        You can override this method to implement a completely custom markup language, although that could be a somewhat daunting task. Some important things to understand:
        • TokenList is a simple list, mostly without any kind of nesting (the exceptions being AttrSlot & AttrSection).
        • Tokens match one-to-one with tags and "static" template content.
        For example, a "section" in a template will be represented by two TokenSection objects in the TokenList, one for the start tag, one for the end tag. Tokens "inside" that section will appear between these two tokens in the TokenList. The same holds true for TokenSlot, TokenInclude, TokenShow, TokenTrim and TokenFillin. The other tag types (such as TokenStatic & TokenAttrSection) appear as singular tokens, since they don't have a closing tag.

      • produce

        public void produce(java.lang.Appendable a,
           TokenList tokens,
           Token lastToken)
        This recreates the original text template from a TokenList. This method is invoked by TemplateErrorInfo and used to find the part of the template where an error was found, then report it to the user.
        See Also:
        TemplateErrorInfo

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
